meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! Welcome back to my humble abode, where the pixelated goodness flows like a never-ending fountain of fun! Today, we're diving into the world of action RPGs with CI Games and HexWorks' Lords of the Fallen. Grab your favorite snack, settle in, and let's get this review party started!

First off, let me say that I'm not exactly the most well-rounded critic out there (I mean, have you seen my gaming backlog? It's like a digital Mount Everest!). But hey, who doesn't love a good underdog story? And boy, do these critics have some opinions to share!

So, what did they have to say about this soulslike game? Well, IGN thought it was "a great Soulsborne" with that killer twist of swapping between two versions of the world. Sounds like a neat idea, right? Unfortunately, those technical issues and weak boss fights were enough to dampen their enthusiasm.

Slant Magazine just loved the darkness they brought to the light (whatever that means...). I mean, who doesn't love a good dose of existential dread in their gaming experience?

Gaming Age thought it was "none of this is to say the game is bad" (yep, that's some top-notch sentence construction right there!). They praised its receptiveness to feedback and quick patching of those pesky PC performance issues. Yay for developers who listen!

Worth Playing loved how Lords of the Fallen innovated and looked good while doing so (gotta give 'em points for originality). And hey, it's always nice when a Soulslike game doesn't feel like more of the same.

SpazioGames, on the other hand... well, they just didn't think it met every expectation or ambition. With technical flaws and gameplay issues galore, they found it quite far from top-notch soulslike games.

GamingTrend enjoyed the entertaining gameplay and challenging-but-satisfying combat (who doesn't love a good fight?). Just don't ask them about those pesky issues.

And finally, God is a Geek thought it was an enjoyable, yet sometimes unfocused game with some truly out-of-this-world aesthetics (astral pun intended).

So, what's the takeaway from all these mixed reviews? Well, for one thing, it seems like Lords of the Fallen is a bit of a mixed bag. You get innovative gameplay and good visuals, but also some frustrating technical issues and design decisions.

In the end, I think this game is worth checking out if you're a fan of action RPGs or just looking for something new to try. Just be prepared for some bumps along the way (like those pesky PC performance issues...).

That's it for today, folks! Thanks for joining me on this review adventure, and remember: always keep your sense of humor intact, even when playing a game that's not exactly top-notch (wink). See you next time!
